questions.question: What's the most effective way to conduct unit testing?
options: Write tests that test the smallest possible unit of functionality so that the tests remain independent.
Hire a team of professional actors to test the units, they'll find the drama in your code.
Skip it altogether; real-world users are the best unit testers.
Write a comprehensive novel about your code instead; the bugs will reveal themselves through the narrative.

questions.question: Why is regression testing so essential?
options: To see how much your code has 'regressed' since the last release.
To ensure new features don't break old ones.
It's not; just release and let users discover the surprises.
It's a covert plot to keep testers employed.

questions.question: What's the best way to handle code reviews during a tight deadline?
options: Skip them entirely; real programmers don't make mistakes.
Conduct reviews during team lunch breaks; nothing like pizza and bugs.
Ask the intern to do the code reviews; they need the practice.
Review code in a haunted house to ensure thorough 'scare-chitecture.

questions.question: What's the secret to successful load testing?
options: Use an army of robots to simulate user traffic; humans are too unreliable.
Load testing is a myth; the cloud magically handles all loads.
Convince all your friends and family to visit your website simultaneously.
Make sure you test on the heaviest load day of the year; nothing could go wrong.

questions.question: How do you ensure thorough security testing?
options: Write all passwords in plain text in the code; that way, everyone can help test security.
Get a colleague who is not associated with your project to test your security. A fresh perspective can help you spot anything you've missed.
Declare your code 'unhackable' and wait for the world to prove you wrong.
Just hope for the best; it's not like anyone would try to hack your code, right?
